Arts and Sciences; and Defense Council will be Joel Woodey,
Junior Arts and Sciences.

Barnstormers Elect
Five New Members
The Barnstormers added five
new members to .their staff as a
result of elections held Tuesday,
according to president Gordon
Stick.
Dave Hochberg, Dick Gatchell,
Dave Scribner, George Edmonds
and Roger McKinley are the new
members,chosen on a point system
requiring' that nominees acquire
twenty points throughout the
course of their workings with the
Barnstormers before being eligible
for election.
The Freshman play, scheduled
for October 12, will be "Ten
Nights in a Bar-room" by William
Pratt, Stick stated.
"I thought this was an excellent year," Stick said, adding that
"this was one of the few years
when we had an audience of more
than one thousand on a certain
night," referring to the Saturday
night performance of "Once in A
Lifetime"

IFB Spring Dance
Scheduled For Gym
Tomorrow Night

The Inter-Fraternity Board's
Spring formal dance will be held
tomorrow night in the Gym, from
nine to one with Ches Kellum's
Orchestra providing music.
Chairman Wes Ownings stated,
"The dance is being held in the
gym because of a mix-up with
the Cotillion Board over the date.
The committee was left with the
choice of the gym or some outside location where liquor was
not allowed. Since most of the
fraternities preferred that liquor
be allowed, the gym, Of course,
was chosen. However, we feel that
the efforts being put into decorations of the gym for the dance
will insure that the location will
not detract from the success of
the dance."
Ches Kellum's orchestra, which
will include a vocalist, last performed for a Hopkins dance at
the Junior Prom in January.

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE TWO

Bain To Head 'Baloo Staff;
Many Positions Still Open
Bill Bain is the new editor-inchief of the 1957 Hullabaloo, according to the 1956 yearbook editor-in-chief Paul Abrams. Assisting him will be Dan Sachs, Business Manager; Ed Siegenfeld,
Editor; and Chris
Managing
Kaahl, Senior Editor.
"We may change printers and
processes, from offset to letterpress," said Bain, adding "we
would get sharper photographic
reproduction with letterpress. It's
more expensive, but the fact that
this year's business staff did such
a wonderful job leads me to believe it can be done again. If possible budgetwise, we might have
colored pictures.
Bain added, "Many staff positions are open and I'm in bad
need of a photographer." More
staff positions will be announced
later this year.
Bain graduated from Lafayette
High School in Lexington, Kentucky, where he was photographic
editor of the school's paper. Managing Editor of the 1955 Hullabaloo, the pre-medical student is
also a member of Pi Delta Epsilon,
national honorary journalism fraternity, and of Alpha Tau Omega.

Honor
A freshman Arts and Sciences
student was found guilty of a
violation in Psychology 1. The
penalty was blacklisting and
failure in the course. After
consideration of certain testimony, the panel voted unanimously to suspend the penalty.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 11, 1956

American Phil. Association
Honors Dr. George Boas
Dr. George Boas, professor of
the history of philosophy at Johns
Hopkins University, has been
named Carus lecturer of the
American Philosophical ,Association for the year 1957, according
to Professor D. W. Gotshalk,
chairman of the Carus lecture
committee.
The Carus lectureship is the
only lectureship sponsored by the
American Philosophical Association as a whole. It was established
in memory of Paul Carus, philosopher, translator, founder of the
Open Court Publishing Company
and editor of The Monist, a quarterly devoted to the philosophy
of science.
Eleventh Lecturer
The first Carus lecture was
given in 1925 by John Dewey and
since then, every two or three
years, a series of three lectures
has been given before a division
of the American Philosophical As-

saciation by the nation's "foremost philosophers."
Dr. Boas is the eleventh Carus
lecturer in the history of the
series and the second member of
the Johns Hopkins' faculty to deliver the lectures.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY IV, 1956

PAGE THREE

New Honor Panel Chosen; Gallagher President Homecoming Float Parade
As H-Club Readies
'Hopkins Fifty Years Ago'
Claxton Named Chairman 'Starlighter'
Dance
(Continued from Page 1)
standards of conduct; the new
Commission will justify its existence by continuing to follow a
policy of emphasis on promotion
of the Honor System," said Claxton. Claxton felt personally that
such emphasis does include the
Gentleman's Code but, he said "I
think non-academic honor should
be handled by the Student Council."
Trial Changes
Claxton indicated that the new
Commission would probably consider altering the trial mechanism
so as to make it more efficient.
He emphasized that any shortening of trials would not be done at
the expense of a fair and just
procedure.
Claxton felt that the past
orientation as regards the Commission and the Honor System
was "excellent." Letters are being
prepared which will be sent to
all faculty members and which
contain suggestions for exam
procedures. The letters contain
suggestions and not requests, according to Claxton.
"The best way to explain the
Honor System is by personal contact," stated Claxton. "The Appeal Board has had little to do in
the past, as there are few ap-

peals. The new Appeal Board
should be able to handle some of
the personal contacts. I also hope
to have more meetings of the entire Commission, which should
draw it together," added Claxton.
• Trials Explained
Claxton attributed the fact that
there were more trials this year
than in the immediate past to
two causes. One, increased emphasis on the promotion of the
Honor System has brought it before more students, and, two,
there has been a greater stress
laid on the fact that possible violations should be turned in. "You
don't have to be one hundred per
cent certain to turn in a violation. If you do that, you're making
a judgment which the Commission is set up to do," said Claxton.
As regards the Orientation
Week program for next year, Claxton stated that more informal
discussions will be held at lunch
hours and that as many Honor
Commission members as possible
have applied to be group leaders.
The skit will be changed slightly;
the motion picture will be shown
again; and a faculty member (as
yet unnamed) will speak to the
freshmen.

The H-C 1 ub's "Starlighter"
semi-formal dance will take place
Saturday evening of Homecoming
Weekend from nine to one, according to president Dick Watts.
The dance will be held on the
terrace and lawn of Gilman Hall
with music being provided by Bob
Emer's orchestra, which will be
seated on the steps of Gilman.
Tables will be situated around
the edges of the Keyser Quadrangle, where the dancing will
take place.
Tickets will cost $2.25 and setups will be sold. Table reservations for the dance may be made
at a cost of $2.00 per table by
contacting Jim Mulligan, Box 447.
All reservations must be made before the dance, and the money
must accompany the reservation
notice.
At elections held Wednesday,
Don Gallagher, co-captain of
football and lacrosse defenseman,
was elected president of the HClub. Bill Civiletti, varsity basketball guard, will serve as vice-president, and three-letterman Jerry
Carr will be secretary, while
lacrosse-man Bob Edwards will
act as treasurer.

This year's Homecoming Float
Parade, sponsored by the Booster
Club to promote school spirit,
will be staged May 19 by representatives of campus activities and
fraternities entering floats on the
theme,"Hopkins Fifty Years Ago."

"Queen Of Homecoming"
The organization entering the
winning float will gain possession
of a small permanent trophy and
the Booster Club trophy for a
year. The queen of the winning
organization will be proclaimed
"Queen of Homecoming" and will
be given "appropriate" gifts. She
will be presented at the H-Club's

Starlighter Dance on Gilman terrace that evening.
To qualify for entry in the
parade, floats must follow the
theme of the parade, and must
cost no more than $25.00, including the rental of the truck and
trailer. Floats may not be wider
than nine feet, higher than twenty feet, nor overhang the front
or rear of the truck by more than
five feet.
Float chairmen will meet in the
office of Mr. Osmar Steinwald.
Weekend chairman, May 18, to
arrange parade positions and to
receive the parade schedule.

Your question is a natural one, Herschel—one we hear
quite often. Du Pont is unquestionably a large company
in total number of employees and in all its operations.
But, actually, Du Pont is made up of ten independent
departments, almost as if it were ten companies under
one management. And it is a fundamental policy at
Du Pont to promote from within and on merit only.
That produces many opportunities for new men, but
in addition there are proportionately more promotions
at Du Pont each year—by reason of expansion and retirement—than you would find in most smaller companies. I say "proportionately more" because Du Pont
has grown at an average rate of seven per cent a year for
the past 153 years—a record that few companies can
match.
And Du Pont is still growing rapidly. Take your field,
electrical engineering. A host of novel and challenging
problems have to be faced, both in new construction and
in maintenance. There are plants to design with features
that have never been applied before; there are new
equipment-control problems to work out, and new engineering processes to pioneer. So,to answer your question
in a word, Herschel, I'd say your chances of promotion
on merit are extremely good at Du Pont!

Batsmen To Face Terrors
Tomorrow At Westminster
Seeking another league victory,
the Hopkins varsity diamondeers
travel to Westminster, Maryland,
tomorrow afternoon to engage the
Terrors of Western Maryland in
their next to last league clash of
the season.
The Jays will end their regular
schedule next Wednesday when
they face the Loyola College Greyhounds at Homewood. When these
teams last met, the 'Hounds eked
Out a one run victory in the final
inning of the game.
Last Saturday the Jays were
downed by Ronnie Sisk and Washington College by a 3-0 count on
the loser's diamond.
The Shoremen jumped out to
a one run lead in the fourth
frame and then added two more
tallies in the seventh inning.
Meanwhile. Sisk held the Jays
scoreless and was in trouble only
In the first and eighth innings,
when the visiting fireballer used
his strikeout pitch to throttle the
Jays.
Barry Burns, Washington second baseman, and Joe Mix led the
Shore attack with two hits each.
Mix slammed a triple in the fourth
frame.
Lauren Cox, Jay shortstop,. and
Frank Hyde paced the seven hit
Jay attack with two singles
apiece. Sam Liko, John Newton
and Howie Alfandre were the other
Jays to collect safeties.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 11, 1956

NEWS -LETTER

Jay Netters Satisfy
Coach Gene Nolan
With Year's Record
"It's been a good year for Hopkins tennis," said coach Gene
Nolan. "We've only lost to Loyola,
who were Mason-Dixon champs
last year, and Maryland."
Coach Nolan is very pleased
with the fine balance on the varsity. "Don Squair, playing number
two man won the only match
for Hopkins against Loyola and
played a fine game," coach Nolan
stated. Al Greenberg beat Mobray of Western Maryland in a
fine match and Herb Butler, playing third man, has lost only two
matches.
Dan Switky has had bad luck
this year, according to Nolan. He
has been ahead at one time in all
of his matches but has lost more
than his share of close ones. Al
Greenberg and Pete Bower have
been playing number one doubles
and have proved a strong duo,
winning a great number of their
matches.
The Fresh squad has a standout player in Bill Torres, ex-City
College star, according to the Jay
Mentor. Nolan said, "Torres is a
shoo-in for the varsity next year
and may break into the first
three."
This year's frosh team is undefeated but coach Nolan feels
they are only an average team.

Unbeaten Frosh Stickmen
To Test Plebes Tomorrow
Placing a string of four successive victories on the line, the
Freshman lacrosse team travels to
Annapolis tomorrow to take on
the Navy Plebes after a threeweek layoff. The game is slated
to begin at 1:30 P.M., preceding
the varsity tussle which will start
at 3:00.

A recent look at the Wittich Trophy standings, which
does not include any of the spring sports, shows Beta Theta
Pi out in front, 20 points ahead of their nearest rival, Delta
Upsilon. The handball, softball, golf, and lacrosse leagues
still list games or matches to be played.

The Plebes are going into the
contest with a record of four victories and two _defeats to their
credit. They were beaten by the
Maryland yearlings 9-4, and by
St. Paul's School 11-6, while they
came out on top of Virginia,
Washington and Lee, Delaware
and Severn. According to Fresh-

man coach Wilson Fewster the
Sailors have four or five fairly
good players. The rest of the
squad is probably composed of beginners.
"On the basis of these facts
and knowing the physical condition of all Navy teams," stated
Fewster, "it would be fairly safe
to predict a team of good runners,
but very little stickwork."
Last week, the baby Jays engaged several local ball clubs in
p r a c-t i c e scrimmages. Fewster
commented
that the
offense
showed a decided improvement,
but the defense was about in the
same condition.

There are two criteria used in
judging whether or not a deferment shall be granted. The first
is the relative standing of a student in his class, and the second
is the student's score on the nationwide test given twice each
year for the Selective Service.
The first school year after a student registers, he is entitled to
an automatic deferment as long
as he remains in school.
"I urge the student to take
the test," Miss Davis stated. "He
should take this test before he
comes up for his second classification."
A score of 85 on the test is necessary in order to defer a senior
entering graduate school, and a
score of at least 70 is needed for
the undergraduate.
In order for a student to be
deferred on the basis of his class
standing, it is necessary that he
be in the upper half of his class
if he is a freshman, the upper
two-thirds if he is a sophomore
and the upper three-fourths if he
is a junior. Seniors hoping to enter graduate school must be in
the upper one-fourth of their
class.

Five New Members
The Barnstormers added five
new members to .their staff as a
result of elections held Tuesday,
according to president Gordon
Stick.
Dave Hochberg, Dick Gatchell,
Dave Scribner, George Edmonds
and Roger McKinley are the new
members,chosen on a point system
requiring' that nominees acquire
twenty points throughout the
course of their workings with the
Barnstormers before being eligible
for election.
The Freshman play, scheduled
for October 12, will be "Ten
Nights in a Bar-room" by William
Pratt, Stick stated.
"I thought this was an excellent year," Stick said, adding that
"this was one of the few years
when we had an audience of more
than one thousand on a certain
night," referring to the Saturday
night performance of "Once in A
Lifetime"

Bain To Head 'Baloo Staff;
Many Positions Still Open
Bill Bain is the new editor-inchief of the 1957 Hullabaloo, according to the 1956 yearbook editor-in-chief Paul Abrams. Assisting him will be Dan Sachs, Business Manager; Ed Siegenfeld,
Editor; and Chris
Managing
Kaahl, Senior Editor.
"We may change printers and
processes, from offset to letterpress," said Bain, adding "we
would get sharper photographic
reproduction with letterpress. It's
more expensive, but the fact that
this year's business staff did such
a wonderful job leads me to believe it can be done again. If possible budgetwise, we might have
colored pictures.
Bain added, "Many staff positions are open and I'm in bad
need of a photographer." More
staff positions will be announced
later this year.
Bain graduated from Lafayette
High School in Lexington, Kentucky, where he was photographic
editor of the school's paper. Managing Editor of the 1955 Hullabaloo, the pre-medical student is
also a member of Pi Delta Epsilon,
national honorary journalism fraternity, and of Alpha Tau Omega.

student was found guilty of a
violation in Psychology 1. The
penalty was blacklisting and
failure in the course. After
consideration of certain testimony, the panel voted unanimously to suspend the penalty.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 11, 1956

American Phil. Association
Honors Dr. George Boas
Dr. George Boas, professor of
the history of philosophy at Johns
Hopkins University, has been
named Carus lecturer of the
American Philosophical ,Association for the year 1957, according
to Professor D. W. Gotshalk,
chairman of the Carus lecture
committee.
The Carus lectureship is the
only lectureship sponsored by the
American Philosophical Association as a whole. It was established
in memory of Paul Carus, philosopher, translator, founder of the
Open Court Publishing Company
and editor of The Monist, a quarterly devoted to the philosophy
of science.
Eleventh Lecturer
The first Carus lecture was
given in 1925 by John Dewey and
since then, every two or three
years, a series of three lectures
has been given before a division
of the American Philosophical As-

saciation by the nation's "foremost philosophers."
Dr. Boas is the eleventh Carus
lecturer in the history of the
series and the second member of
the Johns Hopkins' faculty to deliver the lectures.

Claxton indicated that the new
Commission would probably consider altering the trial mechanism
so as to make it more efficient.
He emphasized that any shortening of trials would not be done at
the expense of a fair and just
procedure.
Claxton felt that the past
orientation as regards the Commission and the Honor System
was "excellent." Letters are being
prepared which will be sent to
all faculty members and which
contain suggestions for exam
procedures. The letters contain
suggestions and not requests, according to Claxton.
"The best way to explain the
Honor System is by personal contact," stated Claxton. "The Appeal Board has had little to do in
the past, as there are few ap-

peals. The new Appeal Board
should be able to handle some of
the personal contacts. I also hope
to have more meetings of the entire Commission, which should
draw it together," added Claxton.
• Trials Explained
Claxton attributed the fact that
there were more trials this year
than in the immediate past to
two causes. One, increased emphasis on the promotion of the
Honor System has brought it before more students, and, two,
there has been a greater stress
laid on the fact that possible violations should be turned in. "You
don't have to be one hundred per
cent certain to turn in a violation. If you do that, you're making
a judgment which the Commission is set up to do," said Claxton.
As regards the Orientation
Week program for next year, Claxton stated that more informal
discussions will be held at lunch
hours and that as many Honor
Commission members as possible
have applied to be group leaders.
The skit will be changed slightly;
the motion picture will be shown
again; and a faculty member (as
yet unnamed) will speak to the
freshmen.

The H-C 1 ub's "Starlighter"
semi-formal dance will take place
Saturday evening of Homecoming
Weekend from nine to one, according to president Dick Watts.
The dance will be held on the
terrace and lawn of Gilman Hall
with music being provided by Bob
Emer's orchestra, which will be
seated on the steps of Gilman.
Tables will be situated around
the edges of the Keyser Quadrangle, where the dancing will
take place.
Tickets will cost $2.25 and setups will be sold. Table reservations for the dance may be made
at a cost of $2.00 per table by
contacting Jim Mulligan, Box 447.
All reservations must be made before the dance, and the money
must accompany the reservation
notice.
At elections held Wednesday,
Don Gallagher, co-captain of
football and lacrosse defenseman,
was elected president of the HClub. Bill Civiletti, varsity basketball guard, will serve as vice-president, and three-letterman Jerry
Carr will be secretary, while
lacrosse-man Bob Edwards will
act as treasurer.

This year's Homecoming Float
Parade, sponsored by the Booster
Club to promote school spirit,
will be staged May 19 by representatives of campus activities and
fraternities entering floats on the
theme,"Hopkins Fifty Years Ago."

"Queen Of Homecoming"
The organization entering the
winning float will gain possession
of a small permanent trophy and
the Booster Club trophy for a
year. The queen of the winning
organization will be proclaimed
"Queen of Homecoming" and will
be given "appropriate" gifts. She
will be presented at the H-Club's

Starlighter Dance on Gilman terrace that evening.
To qualify for entry in the
parade, floats must follow the
theme of the parade, and must
cost no more than $25.00, including the rental of the truck and
trailer. Floats may not be wider
than nine feet, higher than twenty feet, nor overhang the front
or rear of the truck by more than
five feet.
Float chairmen will meet in the
office of Mr. Osmar Steinwald.
Weekend chairman, May 18, to
arrange parade positions and to
receive the parade schedule.

Your question is a natural one, Herschel—one we hear
quite often. Du Pont is unquestionably a large company
in total number of employees and in all its operations.
But, actually, Du Pont is made up of ten independent
departments, almost as if it were ten companies under
one management. And it is a fundamental policy at
Du Pont to promote from within and on merit only.
That produces many opportunities for new men, but
in addition there are proportionately more promotions
at Du Pont each year—by reason of expansion and retirement—than you would find in most smaller companies. I say "proportionately more" because Du Pont
has grown at an average rate of seven per cent a year for
the past 153 years—a record that few companies can
match.
And Du Pont is still growing rapidly. Take your field,
electrical engineering. A host of novel and challenging
problems have to be faced, both in new construction and
in maintenance. There are plants to design with features
that have never been applied before; there are new
equipment-control problems to work out, and new engineering processes to pioneer. So,to answer your question
in a word, Herschel, I'd say your chances of promotion
on merit are extremely good at Du Pont!

Tomorrow At Westminster
Seeking another league victory,
the Hopkins varsity diamondeers
travel to Westminster, Maryland,
tomorrow afternoon to engage the
Terrors of Western Maryland in
their next to last league clash of
the season.
The Jays will end their regular
schedule next Wednesday when
they face the Loyola College Greyhounds at Homewood. When these
teams last met, the 'Hounds eked
Out a one run victory in the final
inning of the game.
Last Saturday the Jays were
downed by Ronnie Sisk and Washington College by a 3-0 count on
the loser's diamond.
The Shoremen jumped out to
a one run lead in the fourth
frame and then added two more
tallies in the seventh inning.
Meanwhile. Sisk held the Jays
scoreless and was in trouble only
In the first and eighth innings,
when the visiting fireballer used
his strikeout pitch to throttle the
Jays.
Barry Burns, Washington second baseman, and Joe Mix led the
Shore attack with two hits each.
Mix slammed a triple in the fourth
frame.
Lauren Cox, Jay shortstop,. and
Frank Hyde paced the seven hit
Jay attack with two singles
apiece. Sam Liko, John Newton
and Howie Alfandre were the other
Jays to collect safeties.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 11, 1956

NEWS -LETTER

Jay Netters Satisfy
Coach Gene Nolan
With Year's Record
"It's been a good year for Hopkins tennis," said coach Gene
Nolan. "We've only lost to Loyola,
who were Mason-Dixon champs
last year, and Maryland."
Coach Nolan is very pleased
with the fine balance on the varsity. "Don Squair, playing number
two man won the only match
for Hopkins against Loyola and
played a fine game," coach Nolan
stated. Al Greenberg beat Mobray of Western Maryland in a
fine match and Herb Butler, playing third man, has lost only two
matches.
Dan Switky has had bad luck
this year, according to Nolan. He
has been ahead at one time in all
of his matches but has lost more
than his share of close ones. Al
Greenberg and Pete Bower have
been playing number one doubles
and have proved a strong duo,
winning a great number of their
matches.
The Fresh squad has a standout player in Bill Torres, ex-City
College star, according to the Jay
Mentor. Nolan said, "Torres is a
shoo-in for the varsity next year
and may break into the first
three."
This year's frosh team is undefeated but coach Nolan feels
they are only an average team.

Unbeaten Frosh Stickmen
To Test Plebes Tomorrow
Placing a string of four successive victories on the line, the
Freshman lacrosse team travels to
Annapolis tomorrow to take on
the Navy Plebes after a threeweek layoff. The game is slated
to begin at 1:30 P.M., preceding
the varsity tussle which will start
at 3:00.

A recent look at the Wittich Trophy standings, which
does not include any of the spring sports, shows Beta Theta
Pi out in front, 20 points ahead of their nearest rival, Delta
Upsilon. The handball, softball, golf, and lacrosse leagues
still list games or matches to be played.

There are two criteria used in
judging whether or not a deferment shall be granted. The first
is the relative standing of a student in his class, and the second
is the student's score on the nationwide test given twice each
year for the Selective Service.
The first school year after a student registers, he is entitled to
an automatic deferment as long
as he remains in school.
"I urge the student to take
the test," Miss Davis stated. "He
should take this test before he
comes up for his second classification."
A score of 85 on the test is necessary in order to defer a senior
entering graduate school, and a
score of at least 70 is needed for
the undergraduate.
In order for a student to be
deferred on the basis of his class
standing, it is necessary that he
be in the upper half of his class
if he is a freshman, the upper
two-thirds if he is a sophomore
and the upper three-fourths if he
is a junior. Seniors hoping to enter graduate school must be in
the upper one-fourth of their
class.

TO THE TOUCH...

Most Effective Speaker
Dr. Moos, a professor of Political Science at Hopkins, will travel
this August to San Francisco to
back President Eisenhower for reelection. Though he and the Senator are on opposite sides of the
political fence Dr. Moos regards
Mr. Humphrey as an "old friend"
and "one of the most effective
campaign speakers in American
politics."
Senator Humphrey and Dr.
Moos first clashed politically in
1940. They agreed to broadcast
a thirty minute debate upon the
controversial topic of a third term
for President Roosevelt.
